Multiple equilibria are thought to exist in several marine and terrestrial ecosystems including lakes
33 , marine sea grass ecosystems
34 , tropical forests, and drylands
35 . As an example we consider the bistability of tropical forest versus savannah. For instance, satellite observations across continents show a multimodality in the probability distribution of tree cover under the same precipitation regime
10, 72 . The likely cause is the competition between tropical grasses and trees and their different vulnerability to fire
73, 74 : in a savannah ecosystem, fire occurs frequently and as grasses can quickly re-establish burned areas they outcompete the slower-growing tree saplings. In contrast, where a forest has established, fire is less likely to occur and the high tree cover can persist at the expense of grasses. Dynamic vegetation models indeed indicate that large subtropical land areas fall into a precipitation regime where several stable states are possible
75, 76 .
